QUANTUM LAYERS OVER SURFACES RULED OUTSIDE
A COMPACT SET
CHRISTOPHER LIN AND ZHIQIN LU

Abstract. In this paper, we proved the quantum layer over a surface
which is ruled outside a compact set, asymptotically flat but not totally
geodesic admits ground states.

1. Introduction
The spectrum of the Laplacian on manifolds is a classic domain of research within geometric analysis. One of its least developed area is spectral
analysis on noncompact, non-complete manifolds. An insteresting paper by
Duclos, Exner, and Krejčiřı́k ([2], 2001) demonstrated the existence of discrete spectrum, or bound states, of the Dirichlet Laplacian acting on L2
functions on a particular type of noncompact, non-complete manifold which
they termed the "quantum layer". In particular, the existence of bound
states means that at least there exists the lowest bound state - the ground
state. The main results in their paper were generalized in [5] and [6] by Lin
and Lu to higher dimensions under more general geometric settings. The
existence of discrete spectrum for the Laplacian is a non-trivial phenomenon
on noncompact manifolds, even when the manifold is complete. The results
in [2], [5], and [6] are rare instances in which the discrete spectrum is clearly
known to exist on noncompact, non-complete manifolds.
We recall the definition of a quantum layer below, following [5].

Before we go any further, let us establish a consensus on the notions and
terminologies from functional analysis used in this paper. A good source
of this can, for example, be found in [7]. We will use ∆ to denote the
Dirichlet Laplacian throughout the paper, which is a self-adjoint exension
in L2 (Ω) of the positive-definite Laplacian ∆ = −div ◦ grad on smooth,
compactly supported functions on Ω. The Dirichlet Laplacian ∆ is thus an
unbounded operator with a dense domain Dom(∆) ⊂ W01,2 (Ω) ⊂ L2 (Ω).
The resolvent set ρ(∆) of the operator is the set of all complex numbers
such that (∆ − λI)−1 exists as a bounded operator on L2 (Ω), and the spectrum σ(∆) is defined as the set C \ ρ(∆). The self-adjointness and positivedefiniteness of ∆ imply that σ(∆) ⊂ [0, ∞). The spectrum can be decomposed as σ(∆) = σdisc (∆) ⊔ σess (∆), where the discrete spectrum σdisc (∆)
can simply be defined as all the isolated eigenvalues1 in σ(∆) with finite
multiplicity and the essential spectrum σess (∆) is simply the complement.
The essential spectrum is stable under compact perturbations in the sense
that σess (∆ + T ) = σess (∆) for any compact operator T . One would like to
think that compact perturbations of the metric on a manifold amounts to
perturbing ∆ by a compact operator. This is a useful idealization. However,
it is heuristic.
In light of the heuristic notion that the essential spectrum is invariant
under compact perturbation of the metric, the following result (for which
its less general version first appeared in [2]) is not surprising.

This was achieved first in [2], and more generally in [5](Theorem 1.1) by assuming L1 Gauss curvature and non-positivity of the total Gauss curvature.
Thus there is the following conjecture:
Conjecture 1. Let Σ be a complete, non-compact surface isometrically
immersed in R3 and asymptotically flat. Consider the quantum layer built
over it. If Σ is not the plane and the Gaussian curvature K is integrable
on Σ, does the Dirichlet Laplacian on the quantum layer have non-empty
discrete spectrum?
R
The remaining case of the conjecture above, which is the Σ K > 0 case, was
answered partially through special examples of surfaces in both [2] and [5].
In particular, in [5](Theorem 1.3) the example of quantum layers over a convex surface (graph of a convex function f : R2 −→ R in R3 ) is demonstrated
to have ground state (assuming asymptotic flatness). A convex surface has
positive Gauss curvature everywhere.
R
We must emphasize that in the proof of (2) for the Σ K ≤ 0 case, there
was no reference to the immersion of Σ in the ambient Euclidean space.
Thus the existence of ground state there is of an intrinsic nature. However,
for the convex surface example, a careful analyis of the (integral of) mean
curvature was used in an essentialRway. Therefore, we believe that in order
to answer the conjecture for the Σ K > 0 case, the mean curvature - or
more generally - the second fundamental form of Σ, must always play a
central role.
In this paper we will discuss another rather general example of surfaces
whose layers possess bound states, and the mean curvature on such surfaces
will be heavily involved in the analysis. We consider embedded surfaces in R3
that is ruled outside a compact subset. A ruled surface is such that for each
point on the surface there passes an Euclidean straight line, called a ruling,
lying also on the surface, and such that a local collection of such lines and
the orthogonal flow lines through them constitute a local coordinate system
on the surface. Since this description is local in nature (at least we can
allow the situation where the rulings end somewhere on the surface), we can
define surfaces which are potentially only ruled outside a compact subset
of the surface. More details about ruled surfaces will be given in the next
section.
Our main reslut is as follows:

a compact subset. Then the bottom of the spectrum of the Dirichlet Laplacian

We end this section with an overview of the rest of the paper. In section 2 we discuss the (local) geometry of ruled surfacs. In section 3 we
give relevant information about the topology of noncompact surfaces with
integrable Gauss curvature. The dicussion there will center around the generalized Gauss-Bonnet Theorem of Hartman [3]. In particular, we will make

3. The Topology of Noncompact Surfaces
The famous Gauss-Bonnet Theorem asserts that the total Gauss curvature of a compact 2-dimensional manifold without boundary is a constant
multiple of its Euler Characteristic. If a surface is complete, non-compact,
but has integrable Gauss curvature, then the total Gauss curvature is no
longer completely topological. In 1957, A. Huber showed that a complete,
noncompact surface Σ of integrable curvature is conformally equivalent to

≥ deg(Q) for all s ∈ (−ε, ε). Moreover, we can choose the chart so that

Proof. By Proposition 1, there exists at least one point p ∈ Σ \ B(R0 ),
H(p) 6= 0, and a ruled coordinate chart x : (−ε, ε) −→ Σ such that x(0, 0) =
p and deg(P ) ≥ deg(Q) at s = 0. Suppose at such a point p = x(0, 0),
the first assertion of the corollary is false. Then by the smoothness of the
coefficients of P and Q in s, there must exist an ε > 0, ε ≤ ε, such that
deg(P ) ≥ deg(Q) at s = 0 and deg(P ) < deg(Q) for all s ∈ (−ε, ε) \ {0}.
Thus the ruling lines that pass through these points must comprise a set of
discrete lines, and hence of measure zero. Then applying the integration of
H 2 argument in Proposition 1, we would get the same contradiction as we
did there.

Remark 3. Our proof depends heavily on the fact that the surface is ruled
outside a compact set. If we assume that the surface is asymptotically flat,
